Hi Bernd,

Thank you so much for replying and your detailed answer.

>I do not understand how you want to test for a dead client.

I am very sorry that I didn't make it easier for you guys, please read my 
reply to Levi for the second attempts in formulating my question.

>sidenote:
>from javadoc Object.equals():
>"For any non-null reference value x, x.equals(null) should return false."

So in my case, if the client process is killed, the client reference stored 
in the server becomes null reference, and so clientObject.equals(null) == 
true.  Could it be the case?  I tested the server and 2 clients locally (I 
have no access to a network system) and it *seemed* (I don't know for sure 
though) to work fine.  Am I missing something?

>However if the tcp connection is not closed properly (client disconnected 
from net,
>client OS crashed, ...) the server ist not informed by the tcp layer about
>it. For such cases you will have to add functionality to your server to 
>actively detect them by a call to a client's method.

I don't know how to implement this.  Right now, all the server's methods are 
declared in the remote interface, and the client gets a remote object of the 
remote interface's type to call its method.  If the server calls the client's 
method, would it be in another remote interface?  And what does the method 
do, or just an empty method and may be some kind of Exception will be 
generated when called on?  

Appreicate your further explaination, thank you again.

Sam
